column1: Yam Stew,root & banana dishes,"The ancient yam is among the oldest roots in Kenya. It is a traditional delicacy of the Meru community.

column1: White Chapati,accompaniments,"This dish is common in many communities in Kenya and even more popular in the urban communities.

and at times eaten with tea for breakfast.  ",30,30,6,"4 1/3 cups (576 g) wheat flour, refined, fortified

column1: Whole Maize Flour Ugali,ugali,"This recipe represents the most consumed Ugali in all communities in Kenya. It is eaten as a main dish

column1: Maize and Finger Millet Flour Ugali,ugali,"This variant of Ugali is prepared from a combination of finger millet and whole maize flour. It is common

column1: Vimumunya vya Sukari (Sweetened Pumpkin & Coconut Milk),desserts and sauces,This is a famous Swahili dessert that is served after meals. It is eaten by the entire family.,5,45,4,"pumpkin, unpeeled (1.7 kg)

column1: Basic Mandazi (East African Doughnuts, Basic),common snacks,"You will find this recipe in any home across Kenya. Preferred for its simplicity, it serves the entire family and

column1: Pancakes,common snacks,"This is a popular recipe among urban dwellers but also common across the country. It is loved for its sim-

column1: Drop Scones,common snacks,"Commonly referred to as “Drops”, these scones acquired their name from the way the butter is placed

column1: Qita,common snacks,"Qita commands respect among the Burji’s as a breakfast dish and an all-day snack. Uniquely prepared with

column1: Busara (Whole Maize and Finger Millet Porridge),porridges,"A typically traditional recipe among the Kuria’s, Busara is a very special porridge. Prepared from keenly

column10: Add the cooked porridge mixture to the sprouted millet mixture in the gourd and stir.
column11: Cover the gourd and set it aside for 1 hour 30 minutes.

column1: Wheat Flour Porridge (Uji wa Ngano),porridges,"The Nubian community in Kenya consider this recipe special to infant feeding. It is enriched with peanut
butter and sugar to give a smooth sweet taste.",5,15,4,"¾ cup (112 g) wheat flour, refined
column4: ½ cup (119 g) peanut butter",Put 4 cups of water into a pot and bring to a boil.
column5: Mix the wheat flour and 1 ½ cups of water in a separate bowl to a smooth consistency.
column6: Add flour mixture into the boiling water and stir until it starts to bubble.
column7: Mix the peanut butter with ½ cup of water and add gradually into the boiling porridge while stirring.
column8: Boil for 3 minutes and add sugar.

column1: Swahili Biryani Rice,rice dishes,"This dish is common among the Swahili community in Kenya. The cuisine is also meat based and special
emphasis is given to finding the right kinds of rice, spices, meat and herbs. It is simply steamed rice eaten
with Biryani stew. It is particularly made using the fragrant species of rice. This colourful dish can be served
for lunch, dinner or during wedding occasions.",5,25,4,"5 3/4 cups (1 kg) raw white rice
column3: 1 g food colour powder, egg yellow
column5: 7 tbsp. (85 g) cooking oil","Take out 2 tablespoons of water and put the rest of the water into a cooking pot, add salt and bring to a boil.
column6: Wash the rice and add into the boiling water. Cover to cook for 10 minutes.
column7: Meanwhile mix the food colour in the 2 tablespoons of water.
column8: Add oil and cook for another 2 minutes.
column9: Add the food colour and simmer for 13 minutes.
column10: Remove from heat.

column1: Wali wa Kuchemshwa (Boiled Rice),rice dishes,"One of the simplest ways that rice is cooked in Kenya is by boiling. This recipe is common in different
communities in Kenya. It is eaten by the entire family often accompanied by a protein rich stew and vege-
tables",5,40,4,"5 2/3 cups (1 kg) raw white rice
column4: 9 cups (1954 g) water","Sort and wash the rice.
column5: In a cooking pot, boil all the water for 2 minutes.
column6: Add salt and rice. Stir and boil for 10 more minutes.
column7: Reduce the heat and cover to simmer for 16 minutes.
column8: Add cooking oil to the rice and stir.
column9: Cover the rice and allow to simmer until it is ready.
column10: Cover with aluminium foil.
column11: Remove from the heat when ready and serve.",138,2,27.2,2.7,0.2,0,0.3,0.46,,,58

column1: Wali wa Yasmin (Onion Fried Rice),rice dishes,"Commonly known as Wali wa Yasmin, this recipe is typical to the Swahili community. It is mainly prepared
during special occasions. It is usually served as a main course accompanied by a variety of stews or broths.
It is enjoyed by the whole family.",35,45,4,"5 cups (898 g) raw white rice
column5: 7 ½ cups (1622 g) water","Wash the rice and soak in 2 cups of water for 30 minutes. Drain and discard the water.
column6: Peel, wash and chop the onions and fry them in a separate pan until golden brown.
column7: Boil 5 ½ cups of water in a pot.
column8: Add salt and the rice into the boiling water. Cover to cook for 10 minutes.
column9: Add onions with the oil with which it was fried in to the rice.
column10: Cover with aluminium foil and simmer for 11 minutes.

column1: Mseto wa Viazi (Potatoes in rice),rice dishes,"This is a common recipe among Kenyan communities particularly those living in the agricultural areas. It
is eaten as a main dish and can be accompanied by a vegetable side dish. Mseto wa viazi is a very basic
rice dish and is loved for its ease of preparation. It is normally eaten by the entire family and serves as an
infant dish as well.",10,60,4,"5 potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, white, raw (468 g)
column3: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (205 g)
column5: 6 tbsp. (63 g) cooking fat
column6: 5 cups (882 g) raw white rice
column7: 11 1/3 cups (2412 g) water
column8: 2 tsp. (9 g) salt, iodized","Peel, wash and cut the potatoes into cubes.
column9: Peel, wash and chop the onions
column10: wash and cut the tomatoes.
column11: Peel, wash and grate the carrots.
column12: Heat the oil in a cooking pot, add the onions and cook until golden brown.
column13: Add tomatoes, salt and stir
column14: cook until tender.
column15: Add potatoes and stir. Add 1 1/3 cups of water
column16: bring it to a boil.
column17: Add the grated carrots after 6 minutes.
column18: Add rest of water (10 cups), stir and bring the mixture to a boil.
column19: Wash the rice and set aside.
column20: Add the rice to the boiling mixture and stir.
column21: Leave the mixture to boil until all the water dries up.",111,1.9,21.1,2.2,0.5,2,0.4,0.38,,,60

column1: Steamed Rice (Wali wa Mvuke),rice dishes,"The special step of soaking rice in this recipe gives a deliciously fluffy dish. Steamed rice is usually accom-
panied by a variety of stews including legume based stews. It is common among Kenyan Indians and the
Swahilis. Usually eaten by the entire family and can serve as part of infant feeding.",35,30,4,"1 cup (193 g) raw white rice
column3: 2 tsp. (9 g) salt, iodized","Sort and soak the rice in 2 cups of water for 30 minutes.
column5: Put the soaked rice into a cooking pot, add the rest of the water (2 2/3 cups) and salt.
column6: Bring to a boil and cook for 20 minutes.
column7: Drain the water when the rice is semi-cooked.
column8: Steam for 10 minutes on low heat.

column1: Mcheleng (Rice with milk),rice dishes,"This creamy smooth dish is unique to the Kalenjin community and is commonly known as ‘mcheleng’. It is
made with milk and milk cream. Loved for its convenience, it is enjoyed by the entire family but mainly a
delicacy for children. It is eaten mainly as a lunch or dinner dish often accompanied by a meat or legume
stews.",10,30,4,"2 ¾ cups (500 g) raw white rice
column4: 1 ¼ cups (284 g) milk cream, cow
column5: 1 tbsp. (14 g) salt, iodized","Put milk, all the water and cream into a cooking pot.
column6: Add salt and bring the mixture to a boil.
column7: Add rice and cook for 20 minutes or until all the liquid dries up.
column8: Remove from heat and cover.

column1: Mukimo wa Njahi (Raw & Ripe Bananas),mashed dishes,"This sweet Mukimo wa Njahi is prepared using ripe banana typical among the Kikuyu community. It was
prepared mainly for lactating mothers and during dowry ceremonies. To date, this remains an important
recipe among the Kikuyu community and is served mainly during Lunch.",10,270,8,"5 1/8 cups (1 kg) njahi dolichos lablab, black beans, raw, dry
column5: 28 ¾ cups (6037 g) water","Sort the black beans, wash and cook in 23 cups of water for 4 hours or until ready or soft.
column6: Mash the black beans until smooth.
column7: Meanwhile, peel the ripe bananas and set aside.
column8: Boil the green bananas in 2 ½ cups of water until they are soft.
column9: Once ready, add the peeled ripe bananas. Add the rest of the water and salt into the mixture.
column10: Let the water come to a boil. Add this mixture into the mashed black beans.
column11: Mash until soft and serve while hot.",151,0.6,26.6,6.4,6.5,1,2.2,0.79,,,63

column1: Mashed Potato and Bananas,mashed dishes,"This recipe is common among the Kisii, Kikuyu and Meru communities due to the abundance of the ba-
nanas and potatoes in these communities. Sometimes it serves as an infant dish. When served as a main
family dish, it can be eaten with a variety of stews or just a vegetable dish.   ",10,45,4,"14 large potatoes, unpeeled, white, Irish, raw (2 kg)
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (134 g)
column5: 1 ¼ cups (186 g) cooking fat
column6: 2 tbsp. (35 g) salt, iodized
column7: 3 1/3 cups (734 g) water","Peel, wash the potatoes and bananas into separate bowls.
column8: Peel, wash and chop the onion. Wash and cut the tomatoes.
column9: Heat the cooking fat in a pan. Add the onion into the pan and cook until golden brown.
column10: Add tomatoes and stir until the tomatoes are cooked or tender
column11: Cut the potatoes and bananas and add into the cooking pot.
column12: Add salt, cover and keep stirring at intervals.
column13: Add all the water and bring to a boil.
column14: Cook until the potatoes and the green bananas are tender.
column15: Mash to a smooth consistency and serve while food hot.",179,8.5,22.1,2.3,2.6,4,1.4,0.36,,,64

column1: Mushenye (Green Maize and Sweet Potatoes),mashed dishes,"This dish is typical to the Luhya community. It is served as a main dish during lunch or dinner. Traditionally
it was eaten plain but can be served with. It usually served with tea.  ",20,280,4,"3 ¾ cups (757 g) beans, kidney, dry
column2: 2 cobs (917 g) green maize, with husks
column3: 4 sweet potatoes, unpeeled, pink skin, raw (1.6 kg)
column5: 1 1/3 cups (323 g) peanut butter
column6: 30 cups (6501 g) water","Boil beans for 2 hours in 21 cups of water.
column7: Remove husks and shell the maize grains into a bowl.
column8: Add the green maize and 4 cups of water to the cooked beans.
column9: Let the maize boil until it is cooked for about 1 hour.
column10: Meanwhile peel and wash the sweet potatoes.
column11: Add sweet potatoes, peanut butter, salt and the rest of the water.
column12: Cook the sweet potatoes in the maize-bean mixture for 1 hour 15 minutes.
column13: Once cooked, mash, remove from heat and serve.",153,4.1,17.6,7.1,8.6,1,2.3,1.07,,,65

column1: Wukunu (Sweet Potatoes & Dehulled Black Beans),mashed dishes,"Wukunu is a traditional dish common in Taita community. It was commonly served during ceremonies such
as burials, weddings, or other special occasions. Traditionally, it was eaten without any accompaniment.
The modern practice incorporates some vegetables or salad.",15,150,4,"2¼ cups (384 g) black beans, dolichos lablab, raw, dry
column2: 7 sweet potatoes, unpeeled, pink skin, raw (1.8 kg)
column4: 2 tsp. (11 g) salt, iodized","Sort the black beans and wash.
column5: Boil the beans in 9 cups of water for 1 hour 20 minutes (or until almost cooked).
column6: While the beans boil, peel the sweet potatoes and set aside covered with water.
column7: Remove the boiled beans from fire and set aside to cool.
column8: Once cool enough to handle, shell the beans (remove the outer skin)/ you can also blanch after cooling the beans to make shelling easier.
column9: Put the shelled black beans into a pot, add 4 ½ cups of water and boil for 4 minutes.
column10: Add the peeled sweet potatoes, salt and boil for 50 minutes or until the sweet potatoes are tender
column11: Remove from fire and mash to a smooth consistency.

column1: Kimanga cha Ndizi (Smoked Green Bananas and Kidney Beans),mashed dishes,"Kimanga is a traditional dish in the Taita community particularly in the highland part of Taita. It is common-
ly made from smoked green bananas that gives the dish its characteristic flavour. It is served during lunch
or dinner as a main meal served to the entire family. Traditionally, it was preferred during drought period
due to its filling effect and usually eaten plain.",10080,140,4,"1 ¾ cups (310 g) beans, kidney, dry
column4: 19 ¼ (4180 g) water","Boil beans in all the water until they are ready.
column5: Without draining the water used to cook the beans, add the smoked bananas, cover and cook for 10 minutes.
column6: Add salt and stir. Cook until the bananas are soft.
column7: Remove and mash.

column1: Kimanga cha Mihogo (Mashed Cassava and Pigeon Peas),mashed dishes,"This is a variant of the traditional Kimanga among the lowland Taita community and other drier parts of
Taita bordering the Kamba community. It was a choice meal during drought and was liked for its filling
effect. In modern times it is still common and eaten as a main meal during lunch and dinner by the entire
family.",10,165,4,"1 ½ (1.3 kg) cassava, unpeeled, raw
column2: 3 cups (541 g) pigeon peas, dry, raw
column4: 21 1/3 cups (4641 g) water","Sort the pigeon peas and wash.
column5: Boil 9 1/3 cups of water in a pot and add the pigeon peas. Boil the peas until soft or ready.
column6: Meanwhile as the pigeon peas boil, peel and cut the cassava into a separate bowl with water.
column7: Add 12 cups of water to the boiled peas and add the cut cassava, and cover.
column8: Boil for 15-20 minutes and add salt.
column9: Cover and cook until the cassava is tender and ready.
column10: Turn off the heat and mash.

column1: Mashed Potatoes,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,25,4,"7 potatoes, unpeeled, white, Irish, raw (1.25 kg)
column3: ½ tbsp. (7 g) salt, iodized","Peel the potatoes and clean them.
column4: Put them in a cooking pot, add salt and cover with all the water.
column5: Bring to a boil and cook until the potatoes are ready and tender.
column6: Drain any excess water.
column7: Mash the potatoes to a smooth consistency and serve warm.",106,0.2,22.8,2.5,1.7,0,1.4,0.32,,,69

column1: Mashed Bananas Plain,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,45,4,"9 unpeeled bananas, green, raw (1 kg)
column3: 1 tsp. (5 g) salt, iodized","Peel the bananas and clean them.
column4: Put in a cooking pot, add all the water and salt.
column5: Bring them to boil until the bananas are tender.

column1: Enriched Mashed Potatoes,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,55,4,"7 potatoes, unpeeled, white, Irish, raw (1 kg)
column4: 6 tbsp. (76 g) margarine","Peel the potatoes, wash and put into a pot.
column5: Add all the water and bring to a boil.
column6: Add salt and cook until the potatoes are tender and most water has evaporated. Leave a little water to help in mashing.
column7: Add margarine.
column8: Mash the potatoes into a smooth consistency.
column9: Remove from heat and serve warm.",141,6.2,18.6,2,1.4,51,1.1,0.26,,,71

column1: Enriched Mashed Bananas,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,40,4,"14 green bananas, raw, unpeeled (1.2 kg)
column4: 8 ½ tbsp. (113 g) margarine","Peel the bananas, wash and put in a cooking pot.
column5: Add all the water and salt.
column6: Boil until the bananas are tender.
column7: Add margarine.
column8: Mash the bananas into a smooth consistency and serve warm.",136,7.8,14.3,1,2.6,63,0.5,0.16,,,72

column1: Kimito (Mashed Beans & Potatoes),mashed dishes,"Kimito is common among the Embu, Kikuyu and Meru communities. It is served as a main dish during
lunch or dinner and enjoyed by the entire family. Traditionally, this was eaten dry but in modern day this
dish is sometimes accompanied by various stews. It is also served to infants above 6 months of age.",10,180,4,"10 potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, white, raw (1.9 kg)
column2: 3 cups (515 g) beans, kidney, raw, dry
column5: 36 1/3 cups (7898 g) water","Sort and wash the kidney beans.
column6: Put beans and 23 cups of water into a pot. Turn on the heat and boil until the beans are soft and ready, about 2 hours 30 minutes.
column7: Meanwhile, peel and wash the potatoes.
column8: Remove the boiled beans and transfer to a bowl.
column9: Put potatoes into a pot and spread the beans on top.
column10: Add the rest of the water and salt. Cover and cook for 50 minutes or until the potatoes are soft and tender.
column11: Drain the excess water if necessary.
column12: Add the cooking oil and mash the content to a smooth consistency.

column1: Kimanga cha Viazi Vitamu (Mashed Sweet Potato & Black Beans),mashed dishes,"Kimanga is a common name for the mashed dishes among the Taita community. This recipe is particularly
unique as it is a mix of sweet potato and black beans. It is usually eaten plain. It is common in both low-
land and highland parts of Taita. To date, this serves as a main meal and is eaten during lunch or dinner.",15,180,4,"4 brown skin sweet potatoes, unpeeled, raw (1 kg)
column4: 28 ¾ cups (6239 g) water","Sort the black beans and wash.
column5: Put the washed black beans into the cooking pot and boil in 18 cups of water for 2 hours or until soft.
column6: In the meantime, peel and cut the sweet potatoes and put them in water.
column7: Add the peeled sweet potatoes, the rest of the water and salt onto the boiled black beans, cover and boil until the sweet potatoes are properly cooked or soft.
column8: Turn off the heat and mash.

column1: Enriched Matoke,mashed dishes,"This a typical infant dish among the Kisii community. It is wonderfully enriched with peanut butter paste to
give it a smooth taste. Infants are fed on this from the age of 6 months onwards. Sometimes, this recipe is
made with some green leafy vegetables.",5,25,4,"9 green bananas, unpeeled, raw, unpeeled (1.5 kg)
column4: 4 ½ cups (968 g) water","Peel and wash the bananas.
column5: Put the washed bananas into a pot, add salt and all the water, and bring to a boil.
column6: Cook until the bananas are ready and tender.
column7: Remove from heat
column8: add the peanut butter and mash.

column1: Nyenyi (Mashed Pigeon Peas & Green Maize),mashed dishes,"""Nyenyi"" is a traditional delicacy among the Embu community. It is made of green maize mashed with po-
tatoes and pigeon peas. It is eaten during lunch and dinner by the entire family. Sometimes, the left-over
of this dish is eaten as breakfast. Traditionally, this dish was eaten dry but in modern times it is eaten with
variety of stews.",10,180,4,"2 ½ cups (474 g) pigeon peas, dry, raw
column5: 4 tsp. (20 g) salt, iodized
column6: 1/3 cup (61 g) margarine
column7: 30 cups (6472 g) water","Sort and wash the pigeon peas. Put into a pot with 23 cups of water and cover.
column8: Boil to cook for 2 hours.
column9: Expose the maize kernels by pulling back the husks and carefully remove the silk.
column10: Remove kernels from the cobs by hand in rows or use a corn zipper.
column11: Wash the maize and add to the boiling pigeon peas. Continue boiling until both are tender and ready.
column12: Remove from heat, drain any remaining water and put into a bowl.
column13: Meanwhile, prepare and cut the potatoes.
column14: Remove the pumpkin stalks, wash and cut the pumpkin leaves and hand blend with salt.
column15: Put the cut potatoes, salted pumpkin leaves, followed by the boiled pigeon peas-maize mixture into a cooking pot.
column16: Add the rest of the water, cover and cook until the potatoes are ready and soft.
column17: Add margarine, remove from heat and mash

column1: Githeri (Sautéed Fresh Maize & Beans),maize dishes,"Another common variant of Githeri is this one that is prepared with fresh maize and dry beans. It is mainly
eaten among communities that grow maize and is common during the green maize season. This is eaten
as a main family dish and served during lunch and dinner.  ",330,10,4,"4 green maize cobs with kernels (1.5 kg)
column2: 4 ¼ cups (740 g) kidney beans, red, dry
column4: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (283 g)
column5: 1 1/8 cups (173 g) cooking fat
column6: 4 ½ tsp. (22 g) salt, iodized","Remove husks from the maize.
column7: Remove the maize kernels into a bowl.
column8: In the meantime, measure the required amount of beans and set aside to soak in 14 cups of water for 2 hours 15 minutes.
column9: Drain and discard the water.
column10: Add the rest of the water into a cooking pot, add the soaked beans and fresh maize.
column11: Place the cooking pot over fire and leave it to boil until it is cooked, and all the water dries up (about 3 hours).
column12: Set aside.",185,7.2,17.8,6.9,10.5,2,2.2,1.32,,<stewing>: Cut onion and put into a pot with cooking oil.
column13: Cook the onions until golden brown.
column14: Add the boiled maize and bean mixture.
column15: Add salt and keep mixing until ready in about 10 minutes.
column16: Remove and serve.,77

column1: Muthokoi (Dehulled Maize and Beans),maize dishes,"This is a traditional dish typical among the Kamba, Taita and Meru communities. The Borana have this dish
by the name Ashir but it’s preparation is unique to their community. The recipe is prepared from dehulled
maize which is boiled together with dry beans. Once stewed it gives a delicious smooth taste. It is mainly
eaten as a main dish during lunch or dinner.",165,15,4,"2 ½ cups (440 g) maize, white, de-germed
column2: 2 2/3 cups (474 g) beans, kidney, dry, raw
column4: 1 onion red skinned, raw, unpeeled (182 g)
column5: 1 ¼ cups (185 g) cooking fat, shortening, commercial, vegetable fat
column6: 4 ½ tsp. (22 g) salt, iodized","Put the maize and beans into a pot and boil in all the water for 2 hours 30 minutes or until cooked.
column7: Drain and keep the remaining water.
column8: Peel, wash and chop the onion into a separate bowl.",161,5.9,19.8,5,4.6,0,1.3,0.59,,"<stewing>: Heat oil in a cooking pot for 1 minute.
column9: Add the chopped onions and cook until soft.
column10: Add muthokoi and salt, stir to mix.
column11: Add the water drained from the boiled muthokoi.
column12: Cover to cook for 3-5 minutes.
column13: Turn off the heat.
column14: Serve.",78

column1: Nchenga/Nzenga (Crushed Maize),maize dishes,"This ancient dish has been a delicacy among the Kamba, Taita and Meru communities for many years as a
rice substitute. The maize is crushed to small size to mimic the size of rice grain, then it is carefully pre-
pared to yield a rice-like dish with a distinct taste. Traditionally, it was eaten on its own or a legume stew
and could also be prepared with a variety of ingredients including meats, legumes or vegetables. It is
eaten by the entire family.",12,60,4,"1 1/3 cups (231 g) crushed maize, white, dry
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (115 g)
column5: 2 ½ tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized
column6: 4 2/3 cups (1004 g) water","Wash the crushed maize and boil in all the water until soft.
column7: Peel the carrot and grate. Wash, peel and chop the onion.
column8: Melt the cooking fat in a pot. Add onion and cook until golden brown.
column9: Add the grated carrot, salt and stir for 2-3 minutes.
column10: Add the boiled crushed maize, stir and cover to cook for 2-5 minutes.
column11: Turn off the heat.

column1: Mchuzi wa Maharagwe (Bean Stew),legume dishes,"The ancient bean stew is chief among the legume stews in Kenya. Different varieties of beans are used to
prepare bean stew by different communities depending on availability. Most communities in Kenya utilize
bean stew as an accompaniment to starchy dishes such as Ugali, rice or chapatti. It is commonly eaten for
lunch or dinner.",160,30,4,"2 2/3 cups (462 g) beans, kidney, dry
column5: ¼ cup (40 g) cooking oil
column6: 2 ½ tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized
column7: 9 stalks (56 g) coriander","Boil all the beans in 9 cups of water for 2 hours 30 minutes.
column8: Prepare and cut the vegetables (coriander leaves, tomatoes and onions) into small pieces in separate bowls.
column9: In a pot, add ¼ cup of oil and turn on the heat.
column10: Add the onions and cook for 7 minutes in a covered pan on low heat.
column11: After 10 minutes, add the tomatoes and cook while stirring to mix.
column12: Add the coriander leaves and mix then add the beans.
column13: Add 1 3/4 cups of water followed by 1 tbsp. salt and cover the pot for 5 minutes. Stir to mix.
column14: Cover the vessel and cook for 4 minutes.

column1: Mchuzi wa Ndengu Kamande (Lentil Stew),legume dishes,"Lentil stew is made from lentil grains which give a characteristic taste to the dish. It is quite aromatic and
provides the desired fragrance as an accompaniment to starch dishes such as rice and chapatti. It is usual-
ly served during lunch or dinner and is common in most parts of the country.  ",60,20,6,"2 1/3 cups (466 g) lentils, dry, raw
column3: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (161 g)
column5: 1/3 cup (63 g) cooking oil
column6: 3 tsp. (15 g) salt, iodized",Sort and wash all the dry lentils. Put in a cooking pot and boil in 9 cups of water for 1 hour.
column7: Remove from heat and set aside.
column8: Wash and cut tomatoes and onions in separate bowls.,108,3,11.1,7.1,4.5,3,2,0.93,,<stewing>: Add cooking oil into the vessel and heat for 1 minute.
column9: Add onions and cook for 6 minutes.
column10: Add tomatoes and salt.
column11: Cook for 7 minutes while stirring to mix.
column12: Add the pre-boiled lentils and mix.
column13: Add 2 2/3 cups of water.
column14: Cover the vessel and cook for 6 minutes.
column15: Remove from heat and serve.,81

column1: Mchuzi wa Ndengu (Green Gram Stew),legume dishes,"Green gram stew is one of the most common legume stews in Kenya. Eaten across the country, it serves
as an accompaniment to starches such as Ugali, rice or chapatti. Sometimes green grams (or Ndengu
as they are commonly known) are used as a key ingredient in making rice dishes as well as mashed with
infant dishes.",60,30,4,"2 ¾ cups (544 g) green gram, dry, raw
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (118 g)
column5: 7 tbsp. (84 g) cooking oil
column6: 2 ½ tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized","Sort and wash all the green grams.
column7: Add the raw green grams to a cooking pot and boil in 8 cups of water for 51 minutes.
column8: Drain and discard the excess water.
column9: Peel, wash and chop the onion and tomatoes.",109,4.2,9.3,6.3,4,4,1.6,0.57,,<stewing>: Add oil to a cooking pot and heat for 2 minutes.
column10: Add the onions.
column11: Cook onions for 3 minutes and then add the tomatoes.
column12: Cook for another 3 minutes and then add the boiled green grams.
column13: Add 2 3/4 cups of water. Add salt and mix.
column14: Cover the vessel and cook for 14 minutes.
column15: Remove from heat and serve.,82

column1: Bean Stew with Milk and Cream,legume dishes,"This dish is very typical to the Kalenjin community. It is usually served with a starch such as rice or Ugali
and serves as a main meal for the whole family during lunch or dinner.",10,150,4,"2 3/4 cups (500 g) beans, kidney, dry
column5: 3 tbsp. (34 g) cooking oil
column6: 2¼ cups (503 g) cow milk, pasteurized
column7: 2/3 cup (139 g) cow cream
column8: 2 tsp. (10 g) salt, iodized","Sort and wash the beans and put into a cooking pot.
column9: Add all the water.
column10: Bring to a boil and cook until the beans are soft and ready. Drain and discard the excess water.
column11: Meanwhile, wash and chop the onion and tomatoes into separate bowls.
column12: In a separate cooking pot, heat oil, add the onions and fry until tender.
column13: Add tomatoes and salt and cook until the tomatoes are tender.
column14: Add the boiled beans, stir and cover. Cook for 2-5 minutes.
column15: Add milk and cream, stir, cover and cook for 10 minutes.

column1: Black Bean Stew (Njahi/Dolichos Bean Stew),legume dishes,"Black bean stew popularly known as Njahi stew, is common among the Kikuyu, Kisii, Meru, Embu and
Luhya communities. It is usually used as an accompaniment to a starch dish such as Ugali, Chapati or rice.
Traditionally, this was a preserve of lactating moms as “njahis” were believed to enhance milk production.",12,195,4,"2 ½ cups (501 g) black beans, dolichos
column2: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (349 g)
column5: 2 ½ tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized
column6: 29 2/3 cups (6438 g) water","Sort the black beans and wash. Put the washed beans into a cooking pot and add 26 cups of water.
column7: Cook until ready or soft.
column8: Remove from heat and drain the excess water from the boiled black beans.
column9: Meanwhile, peel, wash and cut the onion and the tomatoes.
column10: Put oil in a cooking pot and heat for 2 minutes. Add onions and fry until tender.
column11: Add tomatoes, salt and cook until tender.
column12: Add the boiled black beans and simmer for 4 minutes.
column13: Add the rest of the water and simmer for 6 minutes.
column14: Remove from heat.

column1: Mchuzi wa Mbaazi (Pigeon Peas Stew),legume dishes,"Commonly known as ""mbaazi"" stew, this recipe is common among the Kamba community. It is eaten with
starchy meals such as Ugali, rice or chapatti and often served during lunch or dinner. Other farming com-
munities also utilize this recipe in a similar manner.",10,160,4,"2.5 cups (434 g) pigeon peas, dried
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (119 g)
column5: 2 ½ tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized
column6: 18 2/3 cups (4048 g) water","Boil all the pigeon peas in all the water.
column7: Cook until ready or when the peas soften.
column8: Strain the water and keep
column9: set aside the peas separately.
column10: Wash and chop the onions the tomatoes.
column11: Heat cooking fat in a cooking pot for 1 minute, add onions and cook until they turn golden brown.
column12: Add tomatoes, stir and cook until tender.
column13: Add the pigeon peas, stir and cook for 3-5 minutes.
column14: Add salt, water drained from the pigeon peas and stir.
column15: Cover and bring to a boil for 3-5 minutes.
column16: Turn off the heat.

column1: Firinda (Skinned Bean Stew),legume dishes,"Firinda is a dish unique to the Nubian community. It is specially made by skinning boiled beans then sau-
téed in spring onions. It is a popular accompaniment to starchy dishes like Ugali, mkate kuta and rice. It is
served mainly during lunch and dinner to the entire family.",195,120,4,"2 ¼ cups (400 g) beans, kidney, dry
column5: 8 stalks (67 g) spring onions, unpeeled","Sort and wash the beans.
column6: Soak in 14 cups of warm water for 3 hours.
column7: Drain the water soaking the beans.
column8: Remove and discard the skin.
column9: Put the beans into a cooking pot, add the rest of the water and bring to a boil for 2 hours.
column10: Meanwhile, peel, wash and chop the spring onion.
column11: Add the chopped onions, oil and salt into the boiling beans.
column12: Continue boiling until the beans are tender and well cooked.

column1: Ndoto (Sautéed Red Kidney Beans & Red Sorghum),legume dishes,"Ndoto is a traditional dish among the Taita community. It was prepared during “Kuaikwa” (the Taita tradi-
tional initiation ceremony for girls to prepare them for marriage). It was also prepared during weddings.",330,10,4,"3 cups (501 g) red sorghum
column2: 1 ¾ cups (308 g) red kidney beans
column5: 1 ½ cups (176 g) onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled
column6: 3/4 cups (144 g) cooking oil","Sort the beans. Wash and put on the fire in 21 cups of water. Let the beans boil until cooked (2 hours 30 minutes).
column7: As the beans are boiling, sort out the red sorghum.
column8: Once beans are ready, wash the red sorghum and add it into the mixture with the remaining water.
column9: Let the red sorghum boil until cooked (2 hours 50 minutes). Cook until all the liquid is almost dry. Remove from fire.",193,7.9,21.3,5.7,7,0,1.8,0.89,,"<frying>: Peel and chop the onion.
column10: Put in a pot with the cooking oil and fry onion until golden brown.
column11: Add the boiled red sorghum, red kidney beans and salt.
column12: Cook for 6 minutes and remove from fire.",87

column1: Fiqe (Red Sorghum, Beans and Teff Flour),legume dishes,"A mixture of sorghum flour and cooked beans stirred together as a paste and until firm. It is best enjoyed
with a strong cup of black tea. Eaten by everybody. Can also be made with maize flour or any other grain
flour. Traditionally, a bean and ghee must be added. In modern time normal cooking oil is used.",10,165,4,"1 ½ cups (262 g) beans kidney, raw
column4: 1 medium-size bowl (611 g) sukuma wiki leaves, raw
column5: 1 ½ tbsp. (22 g) salt, iodized
column6: 7 tbsp. (88 g) ghee
column7: 8 2/3 cups (1882 g) water","Boil beans in 8 2/3 cups of water until cooked (1 hour).
column8: Wash and cut the sukuma wiki.
column9: Add diced sukuma wiki into the boiled beans in the same cooking pot and cook for 20 minutes.
column10: In a separate bowl, mix the teff flour and the red sorghum flour together.
column11: Add the mixed flour into the mixture of beans and kale. Add salt and stir gently until evenly mixed.
column12: Add ghee after 20 minutes and continue mixing for 10 minutes.

column1: Swahili Biryani Stew (Swahili Spiced Beef Stew),"meats, fish & eggs","Biryani stew is a traditional delicacy of the Swahili community. It is made with meat and heavily spiced
to produce a rich tasty meal. This recipe is sometimes served during special occasions such as weddings
or other social ceremonies. It is eaten by the whole family and can be served for lunch or dinner usually
accompanied by a colourful biryani rice.  ",20,70,6,"1 kg beef, raw, medium fat
column2: 8 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (806 g)
column3: 2 potatoes, unpeeled Irish, white, raw (454 g)
column5: 1 cup (163 g) tomato paste, salted
column6: 1 bunch (60 g) fresh coriander
column7: 1 capsicum, green (242 g)
column8: 2 1/3 cups (468 g) cooking oil
column9: 1 piece (20 g) ginger
column10: 1 garlic, whole (46 g)
column11: 2 ½ tbsp. (37 g) salt, iodized
column12: 4 tbsp. (18 g) pilau masala
column13: 1 cup (242 g) maziwa mala (fermented milk)
column14: 1 ¼ tsp. (2 g) turmeric powder
column15: 2 ¼ cups (511 g) water","Wash and cut the meat.
column16: Boil the meat in 1 cup of water for 20 minutes until meat is tender.
column17: Prepare and put coriander, capsicum, garlic, ginger and tomatoes into a blender and blend to a medium thick juice. Add 1 ¼ cups of water.
column18: Peel, wash and chop the onions into a separate bowl.
column19: Put oil into a cooking pot and heat for 1 minute. Add the chopped onions.
column21: Add the blended paste and stir.
column22: Add meat, turmeric, tomato paste, potatoes, pilau masala and salt.
column23: Cover and simmer until the potatoes are cooked or soft.
column24: Add the fermented milk and continue to simmer for 5 minutes.

column1: Minced Meat Balls,"meats, fish & eggs","This recipe is common in many urban communities in Kenya. It is usually made from minced meat with var-
ious types of fresh spices. It is usually served as an accompaniment with starchy dishes such as potatoes,
rice or spaghetti. As such it is eaten during lunch or dinner and enjoyed by the entire family.",30,75,4,"1 kg minced raw beef, medium fat
column3: 4 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (376 g)
column5: 1 bunch coriander leaves (51 g)
column6: 2 ½ tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized
column7: ½ cup cooking oil (102 g)
column8: 2 tsp. (4 g) cumin seeds
column9: 1 ½ tsp. (3 g) curry powder
column10: 4 Royco® cubes (8 g)
column11: 1 whole garlic (39 g)
column12: ¼ cup (48 g) white raw rice","Pound the minced meat in a mortar.
column13: Prepare and cut the onions as well as the tomatoes and chop into two separate bowls.
column14: Divide the onion, garlic, cumin seed and coriander in two equal portions. Mix and pound one half of each divided ingredient and add into the pounded meat.
column15: Add rice to the pounded mixture and crush the grains.
column16: Fry the other half of onions in ½ cup of cooking oil until they turn golden brown. Add salt and stir.
column17: Add tomatoes and all the water, and then simmer until the tomatoes are tender.
column18: Pound the rest of the garlic, cumin seeds and coriander into the pounded meat.
column19: Work the meat with palms to form balls using ¼ cup of cooking oil.
column20: Add the meat balls into the simmering tomato soup.
column21: Add garlic, curry powder and Royco® cubes.
column22: Simmer for 30 minutes until the meat balls are ready.",157,5.4,18.6,8.1,0.8,9,4.4,1.55,,,90

column1: Stewed Dried Fish,"meats, fish & eggs","This dish is typical among the Luhya and Luo communities. It also commonly known as “Shivambala”.
Frequently, fish that is previously dried (usually split open manner) is stewed with tomatoes and onions. It
is mainly served with Ugali to the entire family either during lunch or dinner.",15,25,4,"210 g dry fish
column3: 1 whole onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (143g)
column5: 2 tbsp. (28 g) peanut butter
column6: 1 g magadi (water and ash)
column7: 13/4 cups (406 g) water","Soak the dried fish in ¾ cup of warm water for 10 minutes.
column8: Chop the onion, cut the tomatoes and place into separate bowls.
column9: Wash the dried fish in the soaking water and drain the water.
column10: In a cooking pot, heat cooking oil, add the onions and cook until they turn golden brown.
column11: Add peanut butter and the grated tomatoes and cook for 3 minutes while stirring at intervals.
column12: Add 1g of magadi and cook for another 2 minutes.
column13: Add salt and the rest of the water and bring the mixture to boil.
column14: Add the washed fish and cook for 10 minutes or until ready.

column1: "Omena Stew" (Silver Sardine Stew),"meats, fish & eggs","""Omena"" as it is commonly known is a tiny fish mainly harvested at the Lake Victoria. As such it is a delica-
cy among the Luo community. However, other communities in Kenya have embraced it as a main protein
dish. It is mainly eaten with Ugali.",15,60,4,"2 cups (128 g) dried omena fish
column2: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (164 g)
column5: 2 ½ tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized
column6: 3 tomatoes, red, ripe (313 g)
column7: 2 ¼ cups (509 g) milk
column8: 1 cup (200 g) cooking oil","Sort the omena (do not wash).
column9: Into a clean pot, add omena, all the water and 1 tsp. salt.
column10: Start the fire, cover the pot and boil for 40 minutes.
column11: Remove from fire, drain and discard the water.
column12: Wash and cut the onions, and tomatoes into separate bowls.
column13: Into a clean pot, add cut onions and cooking oil. Cook for 10 minutes.
column14: Add tomatoes, cover and cook for 3 minutes.
column15: Add the remaining salt, mix, cover and cook for another 2 minutes.
column16: Mash the tomatoes with a fork.
column17: Add the boiled omena and mix.
column18: Add the milk, mix and cover.
column19: Add ghee, mix and heat for 3 minutes.

column1: Fried Tilapia,"meats, fish & eggs","Fried Tilapia is a delicacy that is traditionally relished among the Luo community. The current practice has
seen many other communities adopt this recipe particularly in urban areas. It is usually eaten with Ugali
and served during lunch or dinner to the entire family.",10,30,4,"1 whole fresh tilapia, (approx.834 g)
column3: 1 ½ tsp. salt (7 g)",Prepare and wash the fresh fish.
column4: Score the length of the fish and sprinkle salt on the surface.
column5: Put oil into the pan and heat.
column6: Put in the salted fish into the hot oil and fry until it browns.
column7: Turn to cook the other side.
column8: Place on paper towel to drain the excess oil.,437,28.1,0.3,45.7,0,24,6.2,1.16,,,93

column1: Hydrabadi Biryani,"meats, fish & eggs","This dish is common among the Indian community in Kenya and is served with lightly flavoured steamed
rice. The method of preparation is very key to this recipe and type of fish used. This super spiced king fish
has superior taste and aroma which blends perfectly well with the fragrance of aromatic rice that is served
with it. It is mainly eaten during lunch or dinner by the entire family.",45,45,4,"2 cups (424 g) raw white rice
column3: 1 ½ tsp. (5 g) red chilli powder
column5: 2 tsp. (6 g) coriander powder
column6: ½ tsp. (4 g) cumin seeds
column7: 6 cloves (18 g) garlic
column8: 1 piece (15 g) ginger
column9: 3 green chillies (6 g)
column10: 1 bunch (21 g) coriander leaves
column11: 1 bunch (14 g) mint leaves
column12: 4 ½ tbsp. (67 g) yoghurt
column13: 6 anise (5 g) seeds
column14: ¼ tsp. (2 g) clove seeds
column15: 8 cardamom seeds (2 g)
column16: 6 sticks (3 g) cinnamon
column17: 1 ½ tbsp. (21 g) salt, iodized
column18: 1 bay leaf (1 g)
column19: ½ lemon (11 g)
column21: 8 ¾ cups (1895 g) water","Chop the green chillies and coriander leaves.
column22: Wash and cut the king fish.
column23: Marinade with the dry ingredients (1 ½ tsp. red chilli powder, ¼ tsp. turmeric powder, 2 tsp. coriander pow- der, ½ tsp. cumin seeds, pinch of cloves, 4 anise seeds, 3 cinnamon sticks, 4 cardamoms seeds, the salt, and 3 tbsp. cooking oil. Leave to stand.
column24: Crush ginger and garlic into a paste. Add the paste, coriander leaves, green chillies, lemon juice and yoghurt.
column25: Sort, wash and soak the rice in 4 ¾ cups of water for 30 minutes.
column26: Into a separate pot, add 4 cups of water and the soaked rice and start cooking.
column27: Add the cloves, bay leaf, cardamoms, anise seeds, cinnamon and the cumin seeds.
column28: Cover the rice and boil for 25 minutes until ready and soft.
column29: Remove from heat and drain the water if necessary.
column30: Into a separate pot, add the oil and heat for 1 minute. Add the marinated fish and shallow fry for 6 minutes.
column31: Into the pot used in frying the fish, add the boiled rice (do not stir).
column32: Cover the rice with the fried fish and garnish with mint and coriander leaves.

column1: Stewed Nile Perch,"meats, fish & eggs","This dish is dominant among the Luo and Luhya communities. Other communities as well have embraced
consumption of this recipe and is common in majority of homes in the rural areas. It is mainly served with
Ugali and eaten during lunch or dinner.",5,80,4,"1 kg Nile perch fish
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (91 g)
column5: 3 ½ tsp. (18 g) salt, iodized
column6: 6 2/3 cups (1439 g) water","Wash and cut the fish into 3-4 pieces.
column7: Wash and chop the onion and tomatoes into separate bowls.
column8: Put the fish in a pot and 3 2/3 cups of water.
column9: Turn on the heat and boil for 1 hour.
column10: In a separate cooking pot, add cooking oil and heat for 2 minutes.
column11: Add onions and cook until soft. Add tomatoes and cook until tender.
column12: Add salt, 3 cups of water and stir. Transfer the stewed onions and tomatoes into the boiled fish and stir.
column13: Allow to simmer for 20 minutes and remove from heat.

column1: Stewed Goat Meat,"meats, fish & eggs","Goat meat is common across the country both in rural and urban areas. This dish is usually eaten with a
starchy dish such as Ugali, rice or chapatti. It is served during major meals and relished by the entire family.",7,45,4,"1.2 kg goat meat, medium fat
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (136 g)
column5: 4 tsp. (19 g) salt, iodized","Wash and cut the meat into small pieces.
column6: Heat oil in cooking a pot, add the chopped meat and salt.
column7: Cover and steam for 10-15 minutes to release water from the washed meat. Stir at intervals.
column8: Drain and keep the broth from the meat. Return on heat and cook for 5 minutes while stirring.
column9: Cover to dry. Add onion and cook for 10 minutes while stirring.
column10: Add tomatoes, stir and cook until the tomatoes are tender.
column11: Add the drained broth and stir. Cover and cook until ready.

column1: Nyirinyiri (Camel Meat),"meats, fish & eggs","Nyirinyiri is very tiny tender pieces of meat. It is stored in the oil that was cooked in and lasts very long
without refrigeration. It can be eaten on its own as a breakfast snack or served with mandazi for special
guests or even sprinkled on other foods to liven up the flavour. It is a typical dish among Borana, Gabra,
Rendille, and other pastoralists’ communities.",15,75,4,"1½ kg camel meat
column3: 1 tsp. (6 g) salt, iodized","Cut camel hump into large pieces and put in a heated pan. This is to remove the oil from the hump which was then used in the Nyirinyiri.
column4: Cut the camel meat into small pieces and remove tendons and any other inedible part.
column5: Put the meat in a cooking pot and add a pinch of salt (this is optional as camel meat is usually salty.)
column6: Leave to boil. Before the meat juices runs out, add the prepared camel hump oil (257 g). Keep stirring so that it does not stick to the pan.

column1: Qanchibelo (Beef, Maize & Wheat Flour mix),"meats, fish & eggs","Qanchibelo is a famous is a stew with balls of corn. The best Qanchibelo incorporates ‘shalqeetha’ (Mor-
inga leaves) in the stew for a delightful and healthy meal. Alternatively, sukuma wiki (kale) may be used. It
is a traditional dish among the Burji’s. Qanchibelo is eaten by the whole family as a main dish during lunch
or dinner.",20,120,4,"1 ½ kg of beef, raw, medium fat
column5: 1 tsp. (1 g) red chilli flakes
column6: 1 tsp. (1 g) coriander powder
column7: ½ tsp. (1 g) black pepper
column8: ½ red capsicum (198 g)
column9: 1 green capsicum (210 g)
column10: ½ yellow capsicum (227 g)
column11: 1 onion, raw, red skinned, unpeeled (140 g)
column12: 2 tomatoes, red, ripe (195 g)
column13: 4 1/8 cups (478 g) wheat flour, atta
column14: 2 2/3 cups (339 g) maize flour, white","Cut meat into bite size chunks.
column15: Cut the onion, green capsicum, yellow capsicum, red capsicum and tomatoes.
column16: Remove the stalks from sukuma wiki and tear. Meanwhile, put the meat to boil in 10 cups water for 1 hour 15 minutes or until it softens.
column17: Once the meat is cooked, add salt, red chilli, black pepper, onion, green capsicum, yellow capsicum, red capsicum and tomatoes. Cook for 2 minutes.
column18: Add the shredded sukuma wiki and continue simmering.
column19: Meanwhile, measure 4 1/8 cups atta flour and 2 2/3 cups maize flour into a bowl. Measure 2 ½ cups of water for the flour.
column20: Start mixing using hands until the dough is hard and properly mixed.
column21: Cut dough and press on the palm to oval shapes until all the dough has been used.
column22: Once done, add into the pan containing the meat.

column1: Okra Meat Dish,"meats, fish & eggs","This is traditional dish among the Nubian community. It is prepared with okra and meat giving it a smooth
and soft appeal. The blend of garlic brings out a unique aroma to the dish which is enjoyed by the entire
family. It is often eaten with rice.",15,60,4,"367 g okra
column5: 700 g meat, beef
column6: ¼ cup (40 g) cooking oil
column7: 2 ½ tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized
column8: 2 Royco® cubes (8 g)
column9: 1 tsp. (2 g) curry powder
column10: 65 g coriander leaves
column11: 11/8 cups (253 g) water","Wash and chop the onions, tomatoes, garlic and coriander leaves into separate bowls.
column12: Put the onions in cooking oil in a pot and cook until golden brown.
column13: Add meat followed by salt then stir and allow it to cook for 10 minutes.
column14: Add tomatoes and simmer until the tomatoes are tender.
column15: Add curry powder, 2 Royco® cubes and continue to simmer the meat.
column16: Add coriander, okra and all the water.
column17: Allow to simmer for 5-10 minutes
column18: Add garlic, stir and simmer for another 15 minutes or until ready.

column1: Tsiswa (Stewed Termites),"meats, fish & eggs","This is a traditional delicacy among the Luhya community. It was traditionally eaten by boys after circumci-
sion. In modern practice, this dish is relished by the entire family due to its delicious taste, its satiety effect
and its dense nutrient content. It is usually eaten with Ugali during lunch or dinner and as an all-day snack.",10,30,4,"2 cups (335 g) dried termites, raw
column4: ½ tbsp. (7 g) salt, iodized","Wash the termites.
column5: Peel, wash and finely chop the onions.
column6: Put milk into a cooking pot and place on heat.
column7: Add onions and the washed termites.
column8: Add salt and stir to mix while heating.
column9: Continue stirring and intervals.
column10: Reduce the heat and cook until dry.

column1: Omena wa kukaangwa (Fried Omena),"meats, fish & eggs","""Omena"" as it is commonly known is a tiny fish mainly harvested at the Lake Victoria. As such, it is a
delicacy among the Luo community. However, other communities in Kenya have embraced it as a main
protein dish. It is mainly eaten with Ugali.",10,30,4,"120 g omena, dried, raw
column2: 1 bunch (25 g) spring onion, raw, unpeeled
column5: ½ tsp. (3 g) salt, iodized","Sort the omena and wash in hot water.
column6: Peel and wash the onion and tomatoes
column7: Cut the tomatoes, chop the onions and place into separate bowls.
column8: Heat cooking oil in a cooking pot
column9: add the washed omena and leave to cook for 4-6 minutes without stirring.
column10: Stir to allow for the other side to fry as well.
column11: Remove from the heat and drain the excess cooking oil.
column12: Add the cut onions, turn on the heat and stir to mix evenly.
column13: Cook as you stir continuously to prevent the omena from burning.
column14: Add tomatoes, salt, and stir.
column15: Mash the tomatoes into the omena and continue cooking.

column1: Fried Egg (Mayai Ya Kukaangwa),"meats, fish & eggs","A recipe packed with nutrients, with an old style of cooking, is the fried egg! Everybody in the family
enjoys it with a dash of salt! Served mainly during breakfast, this recipe is an all-time favourite of many
children.",5,1,1,"1 egg, whole (59 g)
column3: 1 tsp. (3 g) cooking oil",Break the egg into a clean bowl.
column4: Heat the cooking oil in a pan.
column5: Whisk the egg with a pinch of salt in the bowl.
column6: Pour the egg on the pan and fry for 30 seconds. Then turn and fry for another 30 seconds.

column1: Omelette,"meats, fish & eggs","Omelette is one of the legendary dishes that have become popular in Kenya among urbanite communi-
ties. Even though it uses locally grown ingredients, it is still viewed as an exotic dish. Mainly served for
breakfast, this recipe is enjoyed by the entire family.",5,15,4,"4 eggs, whole (243 g)
column5: 2 tbsp. (20 g) cooking oil","Break 4 eggs into a bowl.
column6: Heat a little oil on a pan.
column7: Peel, wash and cut the onion and tomatoes into small cubes.
column8: Whisk the eggs in a pinch of salt, add onions and tomatoes and continue whisking until well mixed.
column9: Pour the mixture into the heated greased pan and cook for 6 minutes, turn and cook for 6 minutes.

column1: Spanish Omelette,"meats, fish & eggs","This is a modification of the traditional Spanish omelette. Often made with a variety of chopped vegeta-
bles in beaten eggs, the Kenyan Spanish omelette does not include fried potatoes as is the case with the
typical Spanish omelette. Sometimes, chillies are added for a peppery taste. Though exotic to Kenyan
traditional recipes, it is rapidly gaining popularity among urban dwellers in Kenya as a breakfast favourite
among the adult population.",10,20,4,"4 eggs, whole (221 g)
column4: ¼ cup (33 g) onion, red, raw, peeled, chopped
column5: ½ cup (89 g) tomato, red, ripe, chopped
column6: 1/8 cup (16 g) yellow capsicum, chopped
column7: 1/8 cup (18 g) green capsicum, chopped
column8: 1/8 cup red (20 g) capsicum, chopped","Break the eggs into a bowl and whisk them, then add a pinch of salt.
column9: Add the chopped ingredients and continue to whisk until evenly mixed.
column10: Heat the pan with a little oil for 2 minutes.
column11: Pour the mixture into the pan and allow to cook for 50 seconds.
column12: Then transfer into the oven and cook for 15 minutes.

column1: Likhanga (Stewed Guinea Fowl),poultry,This is a typical Luhya dish eaten during special occasions especially by boys after circumcision.,30,15,4,"665 g whole guinea fowl
column5: 3 tsp. (14 g) salt, iodized
column6: 2 ½ cups (537 g) water","Lightly roast the fresh guinea fowl for 10-15 minutes and cut into small pieces.
column7: Put the pieces into a clean pot and add all the water.
column8: Add salt, cover and boil for 1 hour.
column9: Drain the water and keep in a separate bowl.
column10: Chop the onions, cut the tomatoes and place into separate bowls.
column11: Into the boiled guinea fowl, add onions and cook for 3-5 minutes.
column12: Add cooking oil, stir and cook for 5-10 minutes
column13: Add tomatoes and cook for 2- 5 minutes while stirring.
column14: Add the drained water and cover to cook for 2-5 minutes.

column1: Pumpkin Leaves,vegetable dishes,"Pumpkin leaves are rich in nutrients and are loved by many communities in Kenya. When stir fried, they
are served with Ugali and at times pumpkin leaves are added to mashed dishes.",10,20,4,"14 stalks (110 g) pumpkin leaves, raw
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (44 g)
column5: 2/3 cup (132 g) cow milk
column6: ½ tsp. (3 g) salt, iodized","Wash the pumpkin leaves.
column7: Wash, prepare and chop the onion and tomato into separate bowls.
column8: Put cooking oil in a pan, heat, and add the chopped onions until they brown lightly.Add tomatoes into the cooking pot and cook for 5 minutes.
column9: Add the pumpkin leaves, salt and the milk gradually while stirring.Cook for 5 minutes.

column1: Saget, Terere & Managu (Spider plant, Amaranth & African Nightshade leaves),vegetable dishes,"The mix of saget, terere and managu is a typical way of preparing a deliciously rich vegetable dish among
the Kisii and Luhya communities. This blend of vegetables is served with Ugali.",15,20,4,"451 g spider plant leaves, raw
column5: 2 ¼ cups (511 g) cow’s milk
column6: ½ tsp. (3 g) salt, iodized
column7: 2 ½ cups (539 g) water","Wash and remove the leaves from the stalks.
column8: Prepare and cut the onions.
column9: Bring 2 ½ cups of water to a boil and add the veg- etables to the boiling water. Cover and boil for 10 minutes. Do not stir the vegetables until they are fully covered by the water.
column10: Turn off the heat. Strain and discard the excess water.
column11: Add salt to the boiled vegetables, turn on the heat.
column12: Add half the milk and the onion.
column13: Stir the mixture. Cover and simmer on low heat.
column14: Stir frequently to prevent the vegetables from clumping.
column15: Add the rest of the milk and cook for 3 minutes.

column1: Nderema (Vine Spinach),vegetable dishes,"Vine spinach commonly referred to as “Nderema” is traditional to the Luhya and Kuria communities. It is
usually eaten with Ugali.",15,20,4,"417 g vine spinach leaves, fresh
column5: 3 tbsp. (39 g) ghee","Peel, wash and cut the onions and the tomatoes separately.
column6: Put ghee in the cooking pot and heat for 1 minute on medium heat.
column7: Add the onions and cook for 5 minutes until golden-brown.
column8: Add the tomatoes then the vine spinach and cover the cooking pot.
column9: Cook for 10 minutes then stir the contents.
column10: Add salt, cover and cook for 1 minute.

column1: Terere (Stir-fried Amaranth Leaves),vegetable dishes,"Amaranth leaves commonly known as “Terere” is an indigenous vegetable that used to grow as a weed.
Nowadays, it is cultivated and eaten across all communities in Kenya. When cooked, amaranth leaves
have a distinct aroma and a soft appeal. Most communities use amaranth leaves in mashed infant dishes
but also as a side dish that is eaten with Ugali.",10,20,4,"1585 g amaranth leaves, raw
column5: ¼ cup (45 g) cooking oil","Peel, wash, and cut the onion and tomatoes separately.
column6: Put the cooking pot on the fire and pour in the oil, add the onion and cook until golden brown.
column7: Put the tomatoes into the cooking pot. Continue stirring until the tomatoes are cooked.
column8: Add the amaranth and salt then mix well.
column9: Cover and simmer. Stir momentarily.
column10: Remove from fire when ready

column1: Mashed Pumpkin & Black Nightshade leaves,vegetable dishes,"This vegetable dish is popular among the Kisii community. The added pumpkin gives it a sweet taste to
